Truth 
      Or Dare? 
June 8, 2007
 
Ever 
      told a lie?  Of course you have.  Rare indeed is the person 
      among us who hasnt occasionally stretched the truth.  This Sunday 
      Morning, in our Cover Story, everything you always wanted to know about 
      lies.  OK, maybe not everything.
 As we move into 
      serious vacation season, contributor Janet Maslin stops by to offer us a 
      serious read on the best summer books.
 Then, were off to 
      Paris,  where our 
      David Turecamo  has been sampling the café life, and explains why 
      these legendary hangouts may become a thing of the past.
 Youve probably 
      read that parties in America are getting larger and 
      larger and more lavish by the minute.  This weekend, youre cordially 
      invited to join Serena Altschul as she talks with event planners about 
      this trend.
 And, on the subject of 
      parties, Bill Geist pays a visit to Steubenville, Ohio,  a town 
      that soon will hold its annual festival paying tribute to its most famous 
      citizen  the late Dean Martin (hed 
      have been 90 
      years old this month).
 Finally, from Morley Safer, we 
      have a report on one of our most famous, and familiar, and beloved, 
      painters: Edward Hopper.  We 
      take a close look at the artist, and his art.
 Those stories, 
      and more, this Sunday Morning.  Listen for our 
      trumpet.

Charles OsgoodSundays@cbsnews.com
